reviews.author: UnconMarketeers
reviews.title: An enjoyable analysis course even without the "honors" label
reviews.comment_content:
A fruitful complex analysis course.

Basically covered various essential content, like the point-set topology, continuity and holomorphicity of functions, CR equations, Cauchy-Goursat theorem and Cauchy integral formula, complex logarithm, special properties of holomorphic and entire functions (sharing most properties of harmonic functions discussed in PDE course), Cauchy residue theorem, Rouche theorem and so on.

An optional lecture is given to discuss (relatively) modern and advanced topics, like Mobius transformation and its algebraic properties, Riemann hypothesis and Elliptic functions.
reviews.comment_teaching:
Dr. Cheng's teaching is excellent! Being a postdoc, he knows how to teach clearly and neatly more than many professors.

His English is good, and the speaking pace is moderate. He designed lecture slides per lecture and completed the scheduled content perfectly. Unlike some professors who copied the textbook as powerpoint and not willing to share them freely (well, sharing them is meaningless anyway), he shared the well-designed lecture slides after lecture so that I can follow through the content with it when I watch the lecture video.
reviews.comment_grading:
10+4% from hw, 30% midterm, 60% final.

Before releasing grade distribution, I personally don't think the grading scheme is good, because there is no all-in-final option for this course, while most of the courses I took in this semester offer such choice.

However, my mind changed after releasing grade distribution - With absolute grading scheme (my guess based on distribution), an overall score of 75% is already enough for A range, and 50-75% for B range, 25-50% for C range and so on. I guess you are already safe for getting B or B+ if you only know how to do all the computational problems, plus one or two proof problems!

But of course the most beautiful content in complex analysis is the neat analytic, algebraic and topological properties! Therefore I think it successfully distinguishes A range and B range candidates, depending on how many proofs you can successfully work on.
reviews.comment_workload: 7 homeworks, extracting from the problem sets he designed. About 4-5 problems for each homework. You can do the rest of the problems from the problem sets for practice, but not all problems are worth going through for exam purpose. The grading of homework is very lenient that, even if you make minor mistakes, a full mark may also be given.

reviews.author: alejandro
reviews.comment_content:
Ch 1 The complex plane (arithmetic operations, sequences, point-set topology)
Ch 2 Holomorphic functions (limits, continuity, CR equations, power series)
Ch 3 Line integrals (curves, line integrals, Cauchy-Goursat Theorem, Cauchy integral formula, logarithm)
--------------Mid-term---------------------------------
Ch 4 Consequences of the Cauchy integral formula (many nice and interesting properties of holomorphic functions, some of them very different from real functions)
Ch 5 Isolated singularities (types of singularities, Laurent series, residues, improper integrals, argument principle)
-------------Final--------------------------------------
Ch 6 Epilogue (Mobius transformations, Riemann hypothesis, elliptic functions)

The contents are a lot, but Ch 6 was not covered in the final exam so the exam was still manageable. Our class probably had many IRE/PMA students together with many weaker students, so Henry has made the content flexible by including some supplementary notes apart from his lecture notes. These supplementary notes were optional readings, many of them are for stronger students who want to learn more and deeper about the topics, while some of them are for weaker students (to learn about limsup and liminf for example, although I already learnt it in 3033). I think he has done well in making the content balanced between being suitable for strong and weak students.

In my opinion, I think chapter 4 (consequences of the Cauchy integral formula) is the most beautiful and also the most challenging part of the course (excluding Ch 6 which was not tested). Many properties of holomorphic functions, that are different from differentiable real functions, follow from the Cauchy integral formula. It is challenging because when doing the exercise we need to distinguish among all these properties which ones are more suitable to be applied.
reviews.comment_teaching:
Henry's teaching is clear and organized, and his English is easy to understand. He uploads his lecture notes chapter by chapter before classes, leaving some blanks in examples for us to fill in during the class. If you don't want to copy, you can still get the answers to the blanks because he will update his notes after every class. Although the lecture notes are already nicely written, I still attended classes because he will usually explain the motivation behind definitions and proofs in lecture, before writing them down. I think these motivations and explanations are the things that worth to copy, rather than the blanks. Like in the other review, the slides he prepared are also very useful when you view the lecture recordings again while studying.

His lectures sometimes overrun a bit (about 5-7 minutes), but it was not a big problem in zoom classes because we don't need much time to switch to the next class.

Henry is also responsive to questions asked in emails (he even responds to ig dm haha)

reviews.author: RickyPang
reviews.comment_content:
The content includes the basis stuff in complex analysis

1. Limit and Continuity
2. Analytic Functions
3. Line Integral of Analytic Functions
4. Consequences of Cauchy Integral Formula
5. Isolated Singularities
6. Epilogue (not included in exam this year, mainly about Möbius transform)

For those who first learn complex analysis, Avery's note may seem hard to learn and follow. I suggest Prof. Frederick Fong note instead as Prof Fong explains the concepts in an easy and  simple way. Besides, it is easy to follow.

Reference Books:
"Complex Analysis"; Joseph Bak and Donald J. Newman; Springer Verlag UTM series

reviews.author: maths 4ever
reviews.title: Great course by a great instructor
reviews.comment_content:
Chapter 1 The complex plane
Complex numbers and their arithmetics
Sequence and series of complex numbers
Complex exponential function
Point-set topology in ℂ

Chapter 2 Holomorphic functions
Functions of a complex variable
Limit and continuity of functions of a complex variable
Holomorphic functions
Sequences and series of functions

Chapter 3 Line integrals
Line integrals
Cauchy-Goursat Theorem and Cauchy integral formula
Complex logarithm
-------------------------mid term--------------------------
Chapter 4 Consequences of the Cauchy integral formula (Hardest chapter imo)
Taylor series of a holomorphic function
Morera’s Theorem and its consequences
isolated zeros theorem and identity theorem
Maximum modulus principle and its consequences\
Liouville’s Theorem and its consequences

Chapter 5 Isolated singularities
Laurent series
Classification of isolated singularities
Residues and winding numbers
Evaluation of difficult real integrals using complex line integrals
Argument principle and its consequences
--------------------------Final------------------------
Chapter 6 Epilogue(Not covered in final and no any assignment on it)
Möbius transformations
Gamma function and Riemann zeta function
Elliptic functions

Also supplementary notes on:
The proof of e^(z+w)=e^z*e^w
CR equations in complex coordinates
limsup / liminf (required in exam)
Line integrals along rectifiable curves
Proof of Jordan curve theorem
The "complete" complex logarithm by analytic continuation
Some other applications of improper integrals via residues

Basically a standard complex analysis course in UG level .
reviews.comment_teaching:
Excellent
His notes are very detailed , with examples and proof and seldom have cursed notation(unlike Y*n M*n)

Also he provided lots of problems in his problem sets so that we have enough exercises for exams , and some of his problems in exam are similar to homework problems.

For teaching he can teach some abstract topics (such as point set topology , which I used long time to understand by reading random complex analysis textbook) in a very clear and understandable way .
